content:
Designing the Mozilla Identity 

project brief - confidential

Project Name

Mozilla Identity 

Link to Project Hub

[ link to your Project Hub Wiki Page ]

Rasci

[ link to your RASCI ]

Brief Authors

Tim Murray, Mary Ellen Muckerman

Date of launch

Q2, 2016

Date of brief sign-off

[date]

What Mozilla goal(s) does this support?

Grow our Impact

Impacts product(s)

Mozilla.org, comms/PR, external advertising, internal comms, executive presentations, etc.

Goal: Creating an iconic symbol and system for Mozilla that reinforces and reflects our strategy.

Hypothesis: A lack of brand positioning and stale visual/verbal expression contribute to weak awareness and perception of Mozilla’s purpose and impact. Not enough people know us, recognize what we do or want to help grow the open Internet movement. A clear and compelling brand identity will reinforce our role in the world and help us grow our impact.

Get: our target audiences

To: notice and want to learn more about Mozilla

By: introducing new visual and verbal assets to represent the brand

For the purpose of: growing our audience, deepening relationships, and driving greater impact.

Creative Considerations:  (Imagery, theme, copywriting tone, format, key message(s), inspiration)

The new Mozilla identity should bring to life the brand’s four personality attributes: Gutsy, Creative, Open-minded, For Good.  

Mozilla champions the greater good through a combination of advocacy and activism and is unafraid to be nonconformist, so the identity should be provocative in tone and design.

Mozilla leads technology innovation for the good of the Internet (including Firefox), so the identity should be at the edge of UX, motion graphic, and graphic design trends without being trendy.

As a movement, Mozilla benefits from participation from contributors around the world, so the identity should resonate globally and be open to a maker spirit.

  • For example, might our identity be mutable according to geography - a living logo that invites the participation of our community in some way?
  • For example, might our identity reflect handcraftsmanship versus the cold, machine-made sameness in the design language of leading tech companies.

Success Metrics:

How will you know this project is successful?

  1. By end of 2016, 1% increase in unaided brand awareness as measured by global brand tracker survey.
  2. Increase in key segments (TBD) who associate Mozilla with chosen brand characteristics
  1. Topics Mozilla is likely to engage in for 2016 include: Web Interoperability, Digital Literacy, Digital Rights, Web as the Platform, Economic Vitality
  1. Earned media coverage with a focus on general business, design, and internet sectors.
  2. Adoption by Mozilla community; deprecation of former brand elements

Teams Involved

Tim Murray, Creative Director

Mary Ellen Muckerman, VP of Strategy

Sean Martell, Creative Lead - Brand

Arianna Orland, Creative Consultant

Risks or Dependencies

The Mozilla masterbrand and the Firefox product brand have a symbiotic relationship: Mozilla helps differentiate Firefox within a commodity browser market while Firefox is the product that best shows off Mozilla’s positive impact on the health of the Internet. With hundreds of millions of monthly average users, Firefox is better recognized than Mozilla and the two brands are often conflated. We will be updating the identities of these conjoined twins simultaneously.

We are in the process of  identifying current and aspirational audience targets through research & analysis, segmentation, and sizing. Our hypothetical “conscious chooser*” audience will likely be expanded to include  a discrete set of target personas for Firefox, Mozilla, and both. This work will be completed by end of April, 2016; work in progress will be shared and tested. Simultaneously, the Firefox product team is undertaking market-fit analysis to guide future product evolution, and this work will be completed in the April, 2016 timeframe as well.

Mozilla Marketing is adopting an agile work process defined by users stories, short work sprints, immediate market testing, and rapid iteration. Mozilla will have a bias toward putting work into market to gauge reaction versus planning a large-scale multimedia launch moment. Testing, analysis, and iteration will be an important part of the design process. 

This design assignment excludes business/brand strategy and positioning and focuses solely on creation of the identity, visual communication system and brand expression/application.

In addition to working in a highly collaborative fashion with Mozilla, our agency partner for this assignment will be expected to work in the open with internal client stakeholders and the Mozilla community during all phases of the design.

Mozilla supports the extension of open internet principles, including using open source fonts and/or making any fonts and other graphics free and available for use on the web. Fira Sans, the font currently used for Mozilla, meets many of the qualifications we seek.

Background

In 2015, Mozilla embarked on a journey of discovery that resulted in a clearer understanding of our role in the world: to be a true, personal advocate for online life. Core Mozilla programs and services will be aligned around protecting the health of the Internet, and our identity should reflect this purpose. Mozilla is an activist brand, determined to change the world for the better, and our identity should reflect this spirit.

Prior to this strategic alignment, Mozilla engaged the services of Pitch Interactive to develop a living logo to reflect the ever-changing nature of the Mozilla movement. As with all Mozilla projects, this logo development was conducted in the open; in early 2015, the Mozilla team decided to suspend work on the logo. Mozilla brand positioning and audience identification are now enabling a new brand expression to emerge.

Meanwhile our Firefox product brand is undertaking a similar strategic exercise to focus on quality and innovation.

name: Lucy Harris (@LucyeoH)
content:
Mozilla Brand Identity Initiative - 2016

Mozilla is getting a new brand look.

To reflect and reinforce the updated Mozilla mission and vision announced in Orlando, in 2016 we'll be modernizing our brand identity (logo, colors, font, tagline, and the like). A refreshed brand identity will provide a new badge of belonging to our movement, help us tell the world what we stand for, and attract the attention of people who might never have noticed Mozilla before. It will grow our impact in many ways and launching it will be a milestone.

Currently Mozilla has only a word mark (the word "Mozilla" in the Fira Sans font) and three colors to represent our brand in the world. That's no way to build a Rebel Alliance. Modern communication over mobile devices and using social portals requires a much harder working set of tools. Our organization, especially our global Mozilla communities, is eager to get their hands on a greater range of creative assets.

Want to get involved in this effort?

  • Let us know your thoughts by commenting on the Mozilla Identity project brief : http://bit.ly/1p5fPGO

  • Show us what you think the Mozilla brand identity should look like. Sketch your ideas, make a video, and/or put your thinking into an email to TMurray@Mozilla.com.

  • Check out the Community Design github repo for design challenges related to this brand identity work:  https://github.com/mozilla/Community-Design . Here’s the first challenge: https://github.com/mozilla/Community-Design/issues/39

  • Follow our progress here and on the creative blog https://blog.mozilla.org/creative/

For those of you who want to geek out for a bit on branding, read on.

Our branded house.

A new brand identity is more than putting a new coat of paint on an old house. It’s more like remodeling, starting with a thorough assessment of the structure and its uses, now and in the future.

Redefining the purpose of the house may require work on the foundation, the reconfiguration of walls, the addition of rooms. (That work is underway at Mozilla today.) Only then does the cosmetic work begin. The skin of the house - the brand expression - should not only reflect what stands beneath but suggest the experience people will have once they enter.

An outdated brand expression won’t attract many guests. A fresh one not only reinforces what the brand stands for but catches the eye of passersby who might never have paid attention. Over time with a well-crafted brand identity and expression, a single image distills everything that brand represents. Picture the Nike swoosh.

Our branded house needs to take into account our open source roots, our global footprint and appeal, and our desire to be one Mozilla. It should represent the spirit of our team and the products, technology, and people networks we stand up. We can do this!
